title: Understanding Paired and Unpaired $$t-tests$$
text: A paired $$t-test$$ is used when the samples are related or matched in some way. An unpaired $$t-test$$ is used when the samples are independent of each other.

title: When to Use a Paired $$t-test$$
text: Consider using a paired $$t-test$$ when you have two sets of data that are related, such as measurements taken from the same subjects before and after a treatment.

title: When to Use an Unpaired $$t-test$$
text: An unpaired $$t-test$$ is appropriate when comparing two independent groups, such as comparing the test scores of students from two different classes.

hintAnswer: A paired $$t-test$$ compares two related groups, while an unpaired $$t-test$$ compares two independent groups.
title: Identifying the Correct $$t-test$$
text: Given two groups of data, determine whether they are related or independent to choose the correct $$t-test$$.
choices: A paired $$t-test$$ compares two independent groups, while an unpaired $$t-test$$ compares two related groups.
A paired $$t-test$$ is used for large samples, while an unpaired $$t-test$$ is for small samples.
A paired $$t-test$$ compares two related groups, while an unpaired $$t-test$$ compares two independent groups.
